dcterms:creator: Fabio A. C. C. Chalub
Léonard Monsaigeon
Ana Margarida Ribero
Max O. Souza
dcterms:description: The Moran process is a stochastic process used to model the evolution of allele frequencies in a population with two types of individuals, A and B, where individuals are replaced over time according to specific dynamics.
dcterms:title: Moran process

dcterms:creator: Sewall Wright
dcterms:description: The Wright-Fisher process is a Markov process that models the genetic variation in a population, defined by a transition matrix that describes the probabilities of allele frequencies changing from one generation to the next.
dcterms:title: Wright-Fisher process

dcterms:creator: Fabio A. C. C. Chalub
Max O. Souza
dcterms:description: The Kimura model describes the evolution of allele frequencies in a population, incorporating the effects of selection and genetic drift, and is often used in population genetics to analyze the dynamics of allele frequencies.
dcterms:title: Kimura model

dcterms:creator: N. Champagnat
R. Ferrière
G. Ben Arous
dcterms:description: The replicator model describes the dynamics of strategies in evolutionary game theory, where the fitness of strategies determines their frequency in the population over time.
dcterms:title: Replicator model

dcterms:creator: James Franklin Crow
Motoo Kimura
dcterms:description: The two-player game matrix is used to model interactions between two strategies in a population, where the payoffs determine the evolutionary dynamics of the strategies.
dcterms:title: Two-player game matrix
